thority Addressed Meeting
In Remsen On Friday
--Speaking on "Molecular Rearrangement and Atomic StabiJity," Df. Julius .Stieglitz, University of Chicago savant ar,
thority on spectroscopy, addressed
a large audience in Remsen Hall
last Friday. The lecture was the
third in this year's A. R. L. Dohme
series.
Dr. Stieglitz discussed the necessity of breaking down carbon
linkage in order for living matter
to continue to exist. He visualized this breakdown as due to
local forces-forces comparable
to those that produce landslides
and earthquakes on the earth's
surface. These forces are due to
faults within the molecules
themselves, Dr. Stieglitz asserted.
Use Of Stabilizing Re-Agents
Rearrangement of groups in
organic or inorganic compounds
may be brought about by the use
of certain reagents, the speaker
pointed out. From a practical
viewpoint, the reagents employed
are those which will produce a
stable arrangement.
Dr. Stieglitz compared the
structures of phosphorous trichloride and the very unstable nitrogen trichloride. In the case of
the latter, which has a tendency
to produce a violent explosion,
Dr. Stieglitz said that had it not
been for the fact that he used
goggles once when he suspected
a , slight trace of this compound,
his eyesight would have been
ruined by the shattered glass of
the container. The reasons for
such atomic instability were discussed in great detail with the
use of slides demonstrating atomic structure.
Instability And Carbon Oxidation
One of the important topics
discussed was that of chemical
instability existing because of
the partial oxidation of carbon in
organic compounds.
Prior to the lecture, a tea was
given in honor of the visiting
speaker. His lecture was sponsored by the Dohme Foundation,
which brings prominent men of
science to the University each
year.
